results.title: Whitewashed
results.creator_credit: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Examines the removal of Aboriginal children from their families and their placement in foster homes with white parents, the effect upon the children and the continuation of the practice in NSW today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology

results.title: Tiddalik the frog
results.brief_description: Bob Maza tells the Aboriginal legend of the giant frog, Tiddalik who drank all the water in the land, making a desert. The distraught animals got together and tried to make him laugh, which they finally did, so that the water poured out of him. Bob Maza uses simple stick puppets and colourful backdrops, which could easily be copied, to illustrate the legend.

results.title: Two laws. Part 1. Police times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 1 of a 4-part innovative film entitled “Two laws” which deals with the Borroloola people’s struggle for the recognition of Aboriginal law. This part looks at Borroloola in the 1930’s, dramatically reconstructing a conflict there between Aboriginal people, new white settlers and police in 1933. The other parts of the film are: “Welfare times”, “Struggle for our land” and “Living with two laws”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Two laws. Part 3: Struggle for our land
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 3 of the feature film “Two laws”. Describes Aboriginal attachment to land, conflict over sacred sites, the 1977 Borroloola land claim and the bargaining strategy of the people with the government, the cattle stations and the mining company. The other parts of the film are “Police times”, “Welfare times”, “Living with two laws”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Murawina: where the children play
results.brief_description: Murawina is an Aboriginal preschool in Chippendale - an inner suburb of Sydney. In this film the Aboriginal women who run the preschool express their views on the desirability of running such programs for themselves.
results.description: Murawina is an Aboriginal preschool in Chippendale - an inner suburb of Sydney. In this film the Aboriginal women who run the preschool express their views on the desirability of running such programs for themselves.

results.title: Coniston muster
results.creator_credit: Roger Sandall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Describes the daily activities of Aboriginal stockmen on Coniston Station in the Northern Territory. Examines their attitudes to their work and to the land.

results.title: Robin Campbell: old feller now: memories of a Muruawarri
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: Robin Campbell, an old man of the Murrawarri tribe of the far north west of New South Wales recalls, through dramatic re-enactments by his young relations, how he was taught, as a child, to hunt the emu and make animal tracks, and how he worked as a drover in the 1930’s and 40’s. Narrated by Bill Reid.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara and Goodgabah Productions

results.title: Dugong! Dugong!
results.creator_credit: Australian Museum, Howard Hughes and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Commencing with the telling of an Aboriginal legend about the dugong, the film then shows the hunting, killing and cooking of the dugong by the Aborigines living on Mornington Island. Hunting is now done by motor boat as opposed to the traditional method using nets, which is re-enacted.

results.title: Dreamtime this time dreamtime
results.creator_credit: Air Programs International and Aboriginal Arts Board
results.brief_description: An animated treatment of the Aboriginal legends using children’s illustrations from the book “An Aboriginal children’s history of Australia” is intercut with live footage concerning various Aboriginal issues.
